glsa.title: Multiple Vulnerabilities in ssmtp
glsa.synopsis: There are multiple format string vulnerabilities in the SSMTP package, which may allow an attacker to run arbitrary code with ssmtp's privileges (potentially root).

background.p: SSMTP is a very simple mail transfer agent (MTA) that relays mail from the local machine to another SMTP host. It is not designed to function as a full mail server; its sole purpose is to relay mail.

description.p: There are two format string vulnerabilities inside the log_event() and die() functions of ssmtp. Strings from outside ssmtp are passed to various printf()-like functions from within log_event() and die() as format strings. An attacker could cause a specially-crafted string to be passed to these functions, and potentially cause ssmtp to execute arbitrary code.

impact.p: If ssmtp connects to a malicious mail relay server, this vulnerability can be used to execute code with the rights of the mail sender, including root.

workaround.p: There is no known workaround at this time. All users are advised to upgrade to the latest available version of ssmtp.

resolution.p: All users are advised to upgrade to the latest available version of ssmtp.
